Authors: Gea A.A., Tampubolon S.M., Lakonawa P.
Title: Developing positive multicultural attitudes in student organization
Authors with affiliations: Gea, A.A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Tampubolon, S.M., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Lakonawa, P., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The multicultural mindset and attitude have become compulsory requirements for the professionals in this globalized era of today. For that reason education should help develop students’ skills in this aspect. To portray how student organization fosters the skills this research article is conducted. Using the qualitative research method, it analyzes the management of multiculturalism at BINUS Industrial and Information Business Club (BIIBC). Through interviews, questionnaires and observations, the study will examine and explore how BIIBC manage and develop the multicultural attitude within the organization. © 2017 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cultural diversity; Models of multiculturalism; Multicultural attitude; Multicultural management; Multiculturalism
References: Hartmann, D., Gerteis, J., (2005) Sociological Theory, 23, p. 2; Kapukaya, K., (2010) Journal of Cultural Studies, 8, p. 1; Maxwell, Y., (2011) Canadian Ethnic Studies, p. 43; Munusamy, V.P., (2008) International Management, p. 25; Naseem, M.A., (2011) Canadian Issues, p. 9; Sayles-Hannon, S.J., (2008) In Search of Multiculturalism: Uprooting ‘Whiteness’ in Curriculum Design and Pedagogical Strategies, 66p. , Texas Woman’s University; Song, S., (2005) The American Political Science Review, 99, p. 4; Suparlan, P., (2001) Kesetaraan Warga Dan Hak Budaya Komuniti Dalam Masyarakat Majemuk Indonesia, , Andalas University, Padang

Authors: Patriana Ch R., Irawan I., Tampubolon S., Pane M.M.
Title: Benefits of using smartphones for improving students’ learning outcomes at BINUS University
Affiliations: Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Patriana Ch, R., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Irawan, I., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Tampubolon, S., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia; Pane, M.M., Character Building Development Center, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl.Kemanggisan Ilir III No. 45, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this study was to find out the benefits of using smartphones for improving students’ learning outcomes. This research was based on the quantitative approach and Baker’s theory on Smartphone usage (2005). Data collection was conducted by distributing questionnaires. The questionnaires were constructed by the researchers based on the theory of Baker (2005), involving 200 students of BINUS University. Data analysis was performed by Pearson correlation analysis. The results of this study are there is a positive correlation between portability and motivation (r = 0.335, p < 0.01), a positive correlation between collaboration and motivation (r = 0.342, p < 0.01). There is no correlation between age and motivation either no correlation between GPA and motivation (r = − 0.067, p > 0.05). These results are expected to give impacts on the teaching methods of the lecturers in order to help improve their students’ learning outcomes. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers.
References: Awaludin, W., (2014) Norma Generasi Internet, , https://www.selasar.com/kreatif/norma-generasi-internet; Barker, A., Krull, G., Mallinson, B., A proposed theoretical model for Mlearning adoption in developing countries (2005) Journal, , Department of Information Systems, Rhodes University, South Africa; Corbeil, J.R., Valdes-Corbeil, M.E., (2007) Are You Ready for Mobile Learning?, , Educause, No. 2, University of Texas, Brownsville; Gardner, J.C., (2011) Learning Motivation in Technology-Rich Training, , George Washington University, Washington, D.C; Granito, M.D., Chernobilsky, T., The Effect of Technology on Student's Motivation and Knowledge Retention (2012) NERA Conference Proceeding 2012.
